speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE VII. The French camp, near Agincourt:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter the Constable of France, the LORD RAMBURES, ORLEANS, DAUPHIN, with others

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Tut! I have the best armour of the world. Would it were day!

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: You have an excellent armour; but let my horse have his due.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: It is the best horse of Europe.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Will it never be morning?

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: My lord of Orleans, and my lord high constable, you

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: talk of horse and armour?

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: What a long night is this! I will not change my

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: horse with any that treads but on four pasterns.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Ca, ha! he bounds from the earth, as if his

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: entrails were hairs; le cheval volant, the Pegasus,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: chez les narines de feu! When I bestride him, I

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: soar, I am a hawk: he trots the air; the earth

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: sings when he touches it; the basest horn of his

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: He's of the colour of the nutmeg.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Perseus: he is pure air and fire; and the dull

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: elements of earth and water never appear in him, but

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: only in Patient stillness while his rider mounts

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: him: he is indeed a horse; and all other jades you

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: may call beasts.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and excellent horse.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: It is the prince of palfreys; his neigh is like the

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: bidding of a monarch and his countenance enforces homage.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: No more, cousin.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from the

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: deserved praise on my palfrey: it is a theme as

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: fluent as the sea: turn the sands into eloquent

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: tongues, and my horse is argument for them all:

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: a sovereign's sovereign to ride on; and for the

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: world, familiar to us and unknown to lay apart

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: their particular functions and wonder at him. I

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus:

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'Wonder of nature,'--

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: I have heard a sonnet begin so to one's mistress.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Then did they imitate that which I composed to my

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: courser, for my horse is my mistress.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Your mistress bears well.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Me well; which is the prescript praise and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: perfection of a good and particular mistress.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Nay, for methought yesterday your mistress shrewdly

speaker: Constable
text_entry: shook your back.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: So perhaps did yours.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Mine was not bridled.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: O then belike she was old and gentle; and you rode,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: like a kern of Ireland, your French hose off, and in

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: your straight strossers.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: You have good judgment in horsemanship.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so and ride

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: not warily, fall into foul bogs. I had rather have

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: my horse to my mistress.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I had as lief have my mistress a jade.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: I tell thee, constable, my mistress wears his own hair.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I could make as true a boast as that, if I had a sow

speaker: Constable
text_entry: to my mistress.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'Le chien est retourne a son propre vomissement, et

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: la truie lavee au bourbier;' thou makest use of any thing.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress, or any

speaker: Constable
text_entry: such proverb so little kin to the purpose.

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: My lord constable, the armour that I saw in your tent

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: to-night, are those stars or suns upon it?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Stars, my lord.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Some of them will fall to-morrow, I hope.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And yet my sky shall not want.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: That may be, for you bear a many superfluously, and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'twere more honour some were away.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Even as your horse bears your praises; who would

speaker: Constable
text_entry: trot as well, were some of your brags dismounted.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Would I were able to load him with his desert! Will

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: it never be day? I will trot to-morrow a mile, and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: my way shall be paved with English faces.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I will not say so, for fear I should be faced out of

speaker: Constable
text_entry: my way: but I would it were morning; for I would

speaker: Constable
text_entry: fain be about the ears of the English.

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: Who will go to hazard with me for twenty prisoners?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: You must first go yourself to hazard, ere you have them.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'Tis midnight; I'll go arm myself.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: The Dauphin longs for morning.

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: He longs to eat the English.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I think he will eat all he kills.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: By the white hand of my lady, he's a gallant prince.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Swear by her foot, that she may tread out the oath.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: He is simply the most active gentleman of France.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Doing is activity; and he will still be doing.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: He never did harm, that I heard of.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Nor will do none to-morrow: he will keep that good name still.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: I know him to be valiant.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I was told that  by one that knows him better than

speaker: Constable
text_entry: you.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: What's he?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared

speaker: Constable
text_entry: not who knew it

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: He needs not; it is no hidden virtue in him.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: By my faith, sir, but it is; never any body saw it

speaker: Constable
text_entry: but his lackey: 'tis a hooded valour; and when it

speaker: Constable
text_entry: appears, it will bate.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Ill will never said well.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I will cap that proverb with 'There is flattery in friendship.'

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: And I will take up that with 'Give the devil his due.'

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Well placed: there stands your friend for the

speaker: Constable
text_entry: devil: have at the very eye of that proverb with 'A

speaker: Constable
text_entry: pox of the devil.'

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: You are the better at proverbs, by how much 'A

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: fool's bolt is soon shot.'

speaker: Constable
text_entry: You have shot over.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: 'Tis not the first time you were overshot.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord high constable, the English lie within

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Who hath measured the ground?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Lord Grandpre.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: A valiant and most expert gentleman. Would it were

speaker: Constable
text_entry: day! Alas, poor Harry of England! he longs not for

speaker: Constable
text_entry: the dawning as we do.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: England, to mope with his fat-brained followers so

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: far out of his knowledge!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: That they lack; for if their heads had any

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: intellectual armour, they could never wear such heavy

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: head-pieces.

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: That island of England breeds very valiant

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: creatures; their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Foolish curs, that run winking into the mouth of a

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Russian bear and have their heads crushed like

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: rotten apples! You may as well say, that's a

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Just, just; and the men do sympathize with the

speaker: Constable
text_entry: mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on, leaving

speaker: Constable
text_entry: their wits with their wives: and then give them

speaker: Constable
text_entry: great meals of beef and iron and steel, they will

speaker: Constable
text_entry: eat like wolves and fight like devils.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of beef.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Then shall we find to-morrow they have only stomachs

speaker: Constable
text_entry: to eat and none to fight. Now is it time to arm:

speaker: Constable
text_entry: come, shall we about it?

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: It is now two o'clock: but, let me see, by ten

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Exeunt
